meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>building</radical> has <radical>easy</radical> access to <kanji>sunshine</kanji>. The <kanji>sunlight</kanji> shines right in, because it's a clear building.

When a <radical>spirit</radical> decides to live in your <radical>scarecrow</radical>, you'll be granted good <kanji>luck</kanji> and good <kanji>fortune</kanji>. Crows won't hang out in your farm. Everything you grow will become large and delicious. But not everyone is so lucky that a spirit will decide to live in their scarecrow. So maybe the luck was in you all along!

You can make your <radical>fingers</radical> <radical>branch</radical> out. It's your special <kanji>skill</kanji>, a very advanced <kanji>technique</kanji>. Your fingers branch out into smaller fingers and you can hold things really well. You can type super-duper fast. And you can win any tickle fight. These are skills you have thanks to your branching fingers.

There <radical>go</radical> some <radical>angel</radical>s with <radical>drop</radical>s on their shoulders. Carrying drops like that requires <kanji>technique</kanji>. It’s a real <kanji>art</kanji>.
The <radical>temple</radical> radical and the <kanji>temple</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Brilliant.
A <radical>mountain</radical> <radical>stone</radical> is probably going to be a really big stone. We're talking about a <kanji>boulder</kanji> here.

You pick up your <radical>knife</radical> and <radical>broom</radical> because you're getting ready to <kanji>return home</kanji>. There'll be a lot of work to do when you return home — cooking, cleaning, fixing stuff — so your knife and broom are sure to come in handy.
When you see the <radical>spring</radical> <radical>sun</radical> you know it's finally the  <kanji>spring</kanji> season.

A giant <radical>shrimp</radical> appears on top of the <radical>sun</radical> after it rises high above the <radical>ground</radical>, and this is how you know it's <kanji>noon</kanji>. The shrimp appears on the sun exactly at noon every day, to announce that it's noon.
The <radical>sun</radical> is out, the sky is <radical>blue</radical>, things have begun to <kanji>clear up</kanji>!

<radical>Grain</radical>s look like they're on <radical>fire</radical> in <kanji>autumn</kanji>. They all turn red and orange and brown, the colors of fire. It's also fun to set grains on fire in Autumn, since it's getting colder.
If you want to <radical>say</radical> how big a <radical>cross</radical> is, you have to <kanji>measure</kanji> it. You can't say the size of something without measuring it first.
Take your <radical>yakuza</radical> <radical>knife</radical> and put it in a <kanji>row</kanji> with the others.
This <radical>cage</radical> with <radical>treasure</radical> in it is actually a map of the <kanji>district</kanji> the treasure is in.

<radical>Dirt</radical> is being <radical>anti</radical>-social when it's in the shape of a <kanji>slope</kanji>. Think about it — is there anything more annoying than having to walk up a steep slope? Why is the dirt here forming a slope?! Because the dirt is being anti-social, and a slope is how it tells you to stay away.

A good <radical>ceremony</radical> is under <radical>construction</radical> for a long time. You can't just make up a new ceremony on the spot. A ceremony is done a certain way because that's the way it's always been done. In short, to build a ceremony, you have to create a <kanji>ritual</kanji> first. Then, the ritual can be constructed into a bigger, more lavish <kanji>ceremony</kanji>.

This kanji also means <kanji>equation</kanji> for some reason. Just think of a ceremony that involves doing math and solving equations. How strange would that be? Pretend you're at this ceremony.

To your <radical>leader</radical>, you <radical>say</radical>: "<kanji>Believe</kanji> and <kanji>trust</kanji> in me." The leader doesn't think you can handle your duties, so you have to say this to him. You want him to believe and trust that you're responsible. You can handle this task.
The radical for <radical>courage</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>courage</kanji> are exactly the same.
The <radical>simple</radical> radical and the <kanji>simple</kanji> kanji are the same!

Throw a <radical>cape</radical> over a <radical>creeper</radical>, and suddenly they think they're a big-shot <kanji>director</kanji>. They go around calling themselves managing director of this, director-general of that. They creep into meetings and ceremonies and try to direct the proceedings, all because of that stupid cape.
<radical>Again</radical> and again, <radical>winter</radical> <kanji>change</kanji>s you each year.
The <radical>husband</radical> radical and the <kanji>husband</kanji> kanji are the same. How useful, unlike some husbands, I'd imagine.

Once the <radical>sun</radical> comes out, you can use this <radical>key</radical> to unlock it and take you to any <kanji>previous</kanji> day, even just <kanji>yesterday</kanji>! The sun is in charge of the day changes, so if you use a key to unlock it, you can control the flow of time and return to yesterday, or a previous day in the past. Behold the power of the sun.
To throw <radical>life</radical> out the <radical>window</radical>, use <kanji>poison</kanji>.
<radical>Tsunami</radical>s in the <radical>past</radical> changed the <kanji>method</kanji>s and <kanji>law</kanji>s of today.

A <radical>tsunami</radical> approaches, and anyone who dares to <radical>stand</radical> in front of it will surely <kanji>cry</kanji>. That tsunami is going to hit you hard, and rip you right off the ground you're standing on. Who wouldn't cry?

After a <radical>tsunami</radical>, if you go to a <radical>bar</radical>, you'll find yourself standing in <kanji>shallow</kanji> water. You're just trying to enjoy a drink, but with your feet constantly soaked, it's not exactly pleasant. Here's to hoping the conversations with your date won't be shallow too!

The <radical>thread</radical> you weave together to tell others about <radical>oneself</radical> is the <kanji>account</kanji> of your life. It's your very own <kanji>narrative</kanji>, tying everything you've been through together.

There are many <radical>flowers</radical> in the <radical>center</radical> of <kanji>England</kanji>. It may seem rainy and gray at first, but if you walk right to the center you'll see all the flowers that grow there in the center of the country.

This kanji also means <kanji>English</kanji>, which is pretty similar to England. Just imagine all the people of England walking to the center, where the flowers are, and speaking English to them to help them grow.

You run into someone's <radical>forehead</radical> with your <radical>car</radical>. The big forehead you hit is Kim Jong Un's. You know that now you're going to have the whole North Korean <kanji>army</kanji> coming after you.

You might want to <radical>eat</radical>, but your <radical>anti</radical>-eating stance means your <kanji>meal</kanji> will just sit in front of you, uneaten. Food is meant to be eaten! Stop trying to fast and take a bite.

Your <radical>leader</radical> in <radical>private</radical> is <kanji>Buddha</kanji>. You don't feel the need to tell everyone. But when you're alone you give your time to Buddha and let him lead your life.

The <radical>sun</radical> has an <radical>excuse</radical> for disappearing at <kanji>night</kanji>. The sun gets really tired, same as anyone else – so when night rolls around the sun excuses itself and goes to sleep. It’s a valid excuse.

If you see an <radical>animal</radical> among the <radical>flowers</radical> in a <radical>rice paddy</radical>, chances are it’s a <kanji>cat</kanji>. Cats love rice paddy flowers, almost as much as they love catnip.
Your <radical>fingers</radical> are <radical>private</radical>, no one can see them unless they <kanji>pay</kanji>! And you decide if what they pay is enough to get a peek.
In the <radical>cage</radical> there are some <radical>legs</radical>. They are the legs attached to a <kanji>small animal</kanji>.

The <radical>height</radical> radical and the <kanji>height</kanji> kanji are the same!

That said, there's a secondary meaning to this kanji of <kanji>ten feet</kanji>. So, when you think of height, think of that height as being ten feet tall.

Members of the <radical>tongue</radical> <radical>clan</radical> like to do one thing: <kanji>lick</kanji>. They go around licking everything to mark their tongue clan territory, you know? They even lick each other on the cheek by way of greeting.
